data.reading_mnemonic:
You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a <reading>two two</reading> (<ja>つつ</ja>) wrapping technique.

<ja>つつむ</ja> is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that <ja>包む</ja> can be read as <ja>くるむ</ja> as well. <ja>くるむ</ja> is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. <ja>つつむ</ja> on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.

data.reading_mnemonic:

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>. 

This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you're sinking something else. You can differentiate it from the intransitive <ja>沈む</ja> by imaging that you're watching an enemy ship sink, and they shout out, "Who did this to me!" You respond, <reading>me</reading> (<ja>め</ja>). I did."
data.reading_mnemonic: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "<reading>she's</reading> (<ja>しず</ja>) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>握る</ja> is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a <vocabulary>grip</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>握る</ja>, so get a grip on that!

context_sentences.en: Angry Koichi banged on the desk with his clenched fists.
context_sentences.ja: 怒ったコウイチは、握り拳で机をバンバン叩いた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>揺る</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Viet held onto the branch because Koichi shook the tree.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチが木を揺さぶったので、ビエットは枝に掴まった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Shake</kanji> plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rock</vocabulary> slowly.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>揺る</ja>.

context_sentences.en: It seems that my uncle shook a tree with a beehive in it because he had never been stung by a bee and wanted to try it out.
context_sentences.ja: 僕の伯父さんは、今まで蜂に刺されたことがなくて、どんなものか試してみたかったから、蜂の巣がある木を揺すったんだそうです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>揺る</ja> which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it <vocabulary>to be shaken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be jolted</vocabulary>. You know this because it's really <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) for you to be shaken like this.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>揺る</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The swings at the park swayed in the wind.
context_sentences.ja: 公園のブランコが風で揺れた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>泊まる</ja> is "to stay the night." The noun version is a <vocabulary>overnight stay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleepover</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>泊まる</ja>, so pull from that and you shall know this.

context_sentences.en: My kid was really looking forward to the kindergarten sleepover, but he got a cold and I just made him take antibiotics. So, sadly, he’ll be absent tonight.
context_sentences.ja: うちの子、幼稚園のお泊まり会をすごく楽しみにしてたんだけど、風邪を引いちゃって、今抗生物質を飲ませたところなんです。だから、残念ながら今夜は欠席させて頂きます。

meanings.meaning: To Let Someone Stay The Night

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>泊まる</ja> is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this <vocabulary>to let someone stay over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let someone stay the night</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>泊まる</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I don’t want to have some stranger stay at our house.
context_sentences.ja: うちに知らない人を泊めるのは嫌です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>滑る</ja> is "to slide"? Then, how <ja>台</ja> is a counter for machines? In this case, this slippery machine is a <vocabulary>slide</vocabulary>, more specifically a <vocabulary>playground slide</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>滑る</ja> and <ja>台</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I’m making a slide for my nephew’s birthday, but I’m a little behind schedule.
context_sentences.ja: 甥っ子の誕生日祝いに滑り台を作ってるんですが、少々予定が遅れ気味なんですよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is <kanji>char</kanji>, and a previous word you learned (<ja>焦げる</ja>) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going <vocabulary>to be in a hurry</vocabulary> and you're going <vocabulary>to be impatient</vocabulary>. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, <ja>る</ja>, which stands for <reading>ru</reading>de. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're being rude, but you're also being a big <reading>ass</reading> (<ja>あせ</ja>) with your impatience.

context_sentences.en: Take your time. Other than needing to pee, there is no rush. One day at a time.
context_sentences.ja: 焦るなよ。小便に行きたい以外は、急ぐ必要はないよ。一日一日を着実にな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>焦げる</ja> is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scorch</vocabulary>. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of <reading>gas</reading> (<ja>がす</ja>) to burn whatever it is you burn.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>焦げる</ja>, so if you know that you know this word as well.

context_sentences.en: I always burn my toast completely black.
context_sentences.ja: いつもトーストを真っ黒に焦がしてしまう。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>紛らす</ja> means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word <vocabulary>to be diverted</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be distracted</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>紛らす</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The fever medicine slipped in with other pills and I’m not sure which one is which.
context_sentences.ja: 解熱剤が他の薬に紛れちゃってて、どれがどれだか分かりません。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>distract</kanji> and the adjective version is <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misleading</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know who is particularly <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary>? That <reading>maggie</reading> (<ja>まぎ</ja>) girl. She's confusing because she uses <reading>magi</reading>c (<ja>まぎ</ja>). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

context_sentences.en: It was a basketball after all, but it was really misleading. I thought it looked exactly like a pregnant woman’s stomach.
context_sentences.ja: 結局それはバスケットボールだったんですが、とても紛らわしかったです。私は完全に妊婦さんの大きなお腹だと思っていました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>netting</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen door</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
data.reading_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>網</ja> on its own. We're going to use that reading. Then, add the <ja>戸</ja> reading with rendaku and you have yourself <ja>あみど</ja>.

context_sentences.en: That old screen door is so gross!
context_sentences.ja: あの古い網戸は本当に気持ち悪いね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wild</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> will make for some <vocabulary>stormy seas</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raging waves</vocabulary>. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, <ja>荒</ja> (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and <ja>波</ja> (just the vocab version).

context_sentences.en: He is just a young boy who hasn’t been tossed in the stormy seas of life yet.
context_sentences.ja: アイツはまだ社会の荒波に揉まれた事のないただの若造だよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a sack for your hands... better put, these are <vocabulary>gloves</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of <ja>手</ja> and <ja>袋</ja> as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

context_sentences.en: Why are you running around naked with only gloves on? You’re such an idiot!
context_sentences.ja: どうして裸んぼで手袋だけはめて走り回ってるの？あんたは本当に馬鹿ね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: The novelist finally hit pay dirt with his fifty-fifth novel about dragons.
context_sentences.ja: その小説家は、55冊目の竜を題材にした小説でようやく大儲けすることができた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dragon</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a <vocabulary>tornado</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For <ja>竜</ja> just think about how it's a <reading>stand</reading>ing (<ja>立つ</ja>) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a <vocabulary>tornado</vocabulary>. Your <ja>まき</ja> reading comes from <ja>巻く</ja>, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

context_sentences.en: There was a tornado warning and a power outage last night.
context_sentences.ja: 昨夜、竜巻警報が出て、停電にもなりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fear</kanji> <kanji>dragon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dinosaur</vocabulary>. Dinosaurs are much, much scarier than dragons, and that's why dinosaurs are called fear dragons in Japanese.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: What’s the best way to find dinosaur fossils?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>edge</kanji> of <kanji>wake up</kanji> is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an <vocabulary>omen</vocabulary>... an omen that will show the truth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left wing</vocabulary>, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>左</ja> is the on'yomi reading, <ja>さ</ja>. You can remember this because the <vocabulary>left wing</vocabulary> uses <reading>saw</reading>s (<ja>さ</ja>) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

context_sentences.en: I am so excited that I get to meet with the left wing movement supporter for an interview.

data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <ja>右</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Those in the <vocabulary>right wing</vocabulary> love eating <reading>u</reading>ni (<ja>う</ja>), not because they like the taste, but because uni is expensive. Picture some right-wing people in your mind right now and watch as they try really hard to pretend they like eating uni as they shovel buckets of it down their throats.

data.reading_mnemonic: In each political <vocabulary> wing</vocabulary> there are <reading>two boss</reading>es (<ja>つばさ</ja>). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Those who are able <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The <reading>shino</reading>bi (<ja>しの</ja>).

data.reading_mnemonic: Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be <ja>からい</ja> or <ja>つらい</ja>. The <ja>からい</ja> reading is the spicy one, you can remember that because that <vocabulary>spicy</vocabulary> feeling comes from (<ja>から</ja>) your mouth. The <ja>つらい</ja> reading is the <vocabulary>difficult</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> one. You can remember this because <reading>two Ra</reading>s (<ja>つら</ja>) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as a very similar word, <ja>固い</ja>. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

This word feels pretty formal when used as a noun. You can also add <ja>している</ja> or <ja>した</ja> to mean "rigid," but it doesn't mean that on its own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>leg</kanji> <kanji>book</kanji> is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a <vocabulary>script</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>screenplay</vocabulary>. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

It's <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary>... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>well</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
data.reading_mnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for <ja>戸</ja>, but in this case it's rendaku'd so it becomes <ja>ど</ja> instead of <ja>と</ja>. You didn't learn the kun'yomi version of <ja>井</ja> with the kanji. Think of this <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>, and look inside. There you see an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>), stuck inside. As you pull it out, it scratches your eyes out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>well</kanji> is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a <vocabulary>ceiling</vocabulary>. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cloudy</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get cloudy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become cloudy</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as <ja>雲</ja>, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

context_sentences.en: I don’t like it when my glasses get cloudy from ramen steam.
context_sentences.ja: ラーメンの湯気で眼鏡が曇っちゃうのが好きじゃないんだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The noun version of <kanji>cloudy</kanji> is <vocabulary>cloudy weather</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cloudiness</vocabulary>. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of <vocabulary>fog</vocabulary> you'd find on a window or your glasses.

Despite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

data.reading_mnemonic: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>damp</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be damp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary>. Ewww.
data.reading_mnemonic: You know what's really damp and moist? <reading>Shee</reading>p <reading>me</reading>n (<ja>しめ</ja>) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.

context_sentences.en: I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bride</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary>, because you can't really "to bride" someone.
data.reading_mnemonic: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like <reading>Tots</reading> (<ja>とつ</ja>), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What goes in the <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>? <ja><reading>水</reading></ja>. But, the reading isn't exactly right. It's <ja>みぞ</ja> not <ja>みず</ja>, but close enough to create a hook.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>reject</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>gutter</kanji> is <vocabulary>drainage</vocabulary>, which we also call a <vocabulary>drain</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>. This word covers both the drain in your sink or bathtub, and roadside gutters.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

context_sentences.en: The top team will be awarded with a prize of doing aesthetic waterfall meditation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>waterfall</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are <vocabulary>rapids</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: <ja>滝</ja> and <ja>川</ja>. Careful of the rendaku.

context_sentences.en: My grandma told me that it is very dangerous to swim in the rapids.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lunatic</kanji> or <kanji>crazy</kanji>. The verb version of this is <vocabulary>to go mad</vocabulary> (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or <vocabulary>to go crazy</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are <reading>coming</reading> (<ja>来る</ja>) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

context_sentences.en: "Salmon, let’s get married in Las Vegas this weekend." "Fugu, have you lost your mind?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Lunatic</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is <vocabulary>madness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>insanity</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: You must be insane to decline that offer.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>fly</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

context_sentences.en: It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.
context_sentences.ja: それは、まるで天空を高く翔る不死鳥のようでした。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>孝行</ja> is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your <kanji>parent</kanji>s, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean <vocabulary>filial piety</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>孝行</ja> plus the kun'yomi of <ja>親</ja>. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

context_sentences.en: I think I want to do something to show my filial piety toward my parents.
context_sentences.ja: 何か両親に親孝行してあげたいと思っています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>逃す</ja> is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your <kanji>see</kanji>ing, then you are going <vocabulary>to overlook</vocabulary> it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>見</ja> and <ja>逃す</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I hadn’t noticed that there was a loophole in the law until now.
context_sentences.ja: その法律に抜け穴があることを今の今まで見逃していました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>吹く</ja> is "to blow" and <ja>出す</ja> is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need <vocabulary>to begin to blow</vocabulary> to do that!
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>吹く</ja> and <ja>出す</ja>.

context_sentences.en: She chuckled when she saw my new hairstyle. That’s rude, isn’t it?
context_sentences.ja: 俺の新しい髪型を見て、あいつプッと吹き出したんだぜ。失礼だよな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>吹く</ja> is "to blow" and <ja>込む</ja> is "to be crowded." So if you blow into something to the point where it's crowded, you are blowing into it, making this word "<vocabulary>to blow in</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>吹く</ja> and <ja>込む</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The reality is that the house is so old that the rain and wind blows in whenever a storm comes.
context_sentences.ja: 家はおんぼろで、嵐が来る度に雨風が吹き込むのが現実です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>口笛</ja> is "whistling." So, if you're <kanji>blow</kanji>ing your whistle you're going <vocabulary>to whistle</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are of <ja>口笛</ja> and the reading you learned from <ja>吹</ja>.

context_sentences.en: What attracts you to whistling?
context_sentences.ja: 口笛を吹くことにどんな魅力を感じますか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dilute</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dilute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to water down</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>薄い</ja>, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

context_sentences.en: This miso soup is too salty. Can you water down a little bit?
context_sentences.ja: この味噌汁はしょっぱすぎるよ。もうちょっと薄めてもらってもいいかな？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>逃げる</ja> and <ja>逃す</ja>. This one is <ja>逃れる</ja>. This one simply means <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is the same reading you learned for <ja>逃す</ja>, so you should be able to read this word as well.

context_sentences.en: I’m thinking about how to escape from zombies if they actually showed up.
context_sentences.ja: 万が一ゾンビが実際に現れた場合を想定して、どうやってゾンビから逃れるのかを考えているんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The thing you want to <kanji>take</kanji> has <kanji>escape</kanji>d. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is <vocabulary>to fail to catch</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>取る</ja> and <ja>逃がす</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Don’t you think pretending that you failed to catch the criminal is a bit overkill?
context_sentences.ja: 犯罪者を取り逃がすふりをするのは、ちょっとやり過ぎじゃない？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>吹く</ja> is "to blow" and that <ja>飛ばす</ja> is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going <vocabulary>to blow away</vocabulary> it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>吹く</ja> and <ja>飛ばす</ja>, put together.

context_sentences.en: Let’s go to the party and brush off your depression.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <ja>伺う</ja> is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say <vocabulary>inquiry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary>. In other words, a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. It can also mean a <vocabulary>visit</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>伺う</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Could I inquire about your blog’s URL, please?
context_sentences.ja: あなたのブログのURLをお伺いしてもよろしいですか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>群れる</ja>, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a little different from <ja>群れる</ja>, though. There's an extra <ja>ら</ja> in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small <ja><reading>村</reading></ja> (<ja>むら</ja>). There's a <ja>村</ja> reunion going on, that's why.

context_sentences.en: We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.
context_sentences.ja: 空港に到着するとファンが群がっていて、驚きましたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conceal</kanji>, but as a verb, this word means <vocabulary>to go under</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>. Most commonly, this word means <vocabulary>to dive underwater</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go underground</vocabulary>. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!
data.reading_mnemonic:
潜る has two possible readings: <ja>もぐる</ja> and <ja>くぐる</ja>. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on <ja>もぐる</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get <reading>mo' goo</reading> (<ja>もぐ</ja>) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

context_sentences.en: I saw a mole going underground.
context_sentences.ja: モグラが土の下に潜って行くところを見ました。

context_sentences.en: How long can you stay underwater?
context_sentences.ja: 水の中にどのぐらいの間潜っていられますか。

context_sentences.en: My dog learned a trick to jump through a hula hoop.
context_sentences.ja: うちの犬は、フラフープをジャンプして潜る技を身につけました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for <ja>合</ja> is <kanji>join</kanji>, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is <vocabulary>to join together</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>to unify</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>合う</ja>, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

context_sentences.en: We joined all the red and white wires together.

context_sentences.en: Hey, Steve. You’ve been living in Japan for a pretty long time now so don’t you think it’s time for you to adjust to Japanese customs? Stop being so picky and start eating fish.
context_sentences.ja: おい、スティーヴ！お前はもうずいぶん長く日本に住んでいるんだから、そろそろ日本の習慣とかに合わせたほうがいいんじゃないのか？好き嫌いは止めて、魚も食べるようにしろよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a <vocabulary>bed</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>crib</vocabulary>. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for <ja>床</ja>. You take <ja>とこ</ja> and rendaku it into <ja>どこ</ja>. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "<reading>where</reading> (<ja>どこ</ja>) is it?"

context_sentences.en: "Come now, isn’t it about time for bed?" My grandfather used to say that to me every night.
context_sentences.ja: 「さぁ、そろそろ寝床に着く時間じゃぞ。」子供の頃、毎晩祖父にこう言われました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>堅い</ja> is "solid" or "tough." When your <kanji>hand</kanji> is <kanji>solid</kanji> and tough, it's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steady</vocabulary>. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the two words <ja>手</ja> and <ja>堅い</ja> combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

context_sentences.en: I’m thinking of learning how to become an undertaker because it looks like a pretty secure job.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>荒れる</ja> is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying <vocabulary>to lay waste</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to devastate</vocabulary> everything around you.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>荒れる</ja>.

context_sentences.en: My car was broken into last night and my mac was stolen.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>荒い</ja> is <kanji>rough</kanji>. Double that to <ja>荒々しい</ja> and you have the same thing: <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>荒い</ja>. Since you already know that <ja>々</ja> means it repeats, you already know this reading!

context_sentences.en: In a wild voice he proclaimed that he was totally “pissed off” at his wife for "pissing" on his face every night while he was sleeping.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <ja>趣味</ja> is your hobby. It's the thing you do on habit. A <kanji>bad</kanji> hobby is a habit that you do all the time that's no good. This is a <vocabulary>bad habit</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: My mom forbade my dad from collecting tasteless dolls.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <ja>包み</ja> is a <kanji>bundle</kanji> or <kanji>package</kanji>, and <ja>紙</ja> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be <vocabulary>wrapping paper</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>包み</ja> and <ja>紙</ja> combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

context_sentences.en: There is braille on this wrapping paper.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tide</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tidal hour</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the individual words, <ja>潮</ja> and <ja>時</ja>. Watch out for the rendaku.

context_sentences.en: It’s high time that you quit smoking. Go get some nicotine patches right now.
context_sentences.ja: 今こそタバコをやめる潮時だ。今すぐニコチンパッチを買いに行くんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> isn't what you think, most likely. This is the <vocabulary>Japan current</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Kuroshio Current</vocabulary>. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. <ja>黒</ja> and <ja>潮</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Where exactly is the basin of the Kuroshio Current?
context_sentences.ja: 黒潮の流域とは正確にはどこになりますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rub</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scrub</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
If you're going <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> me like that, I'm going to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The <reading>cos</reading>t  (<ja>こす</ja>) of your rubbing actions will be high.
    
So this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use <ja>する</ja> for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while <ja>こする</ja> means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.

context_sentences.en: I was rubbing my eyes because of my allergies and one of my contact lenses was torn.
context_sentences.ja: 花粉症で目を擦ってたら、片方のコンタクトレンズが破けました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>小</ja> (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and <ja>包み</ja>, with the <ja>み</ja> pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see <ja>づ</ja> too often.

context_sentences.en: This package is just a symbol of our friendship.
context_sentences.ja: この小包は、ほんの友情の印です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>particle</kanji> (<ja>粒子</ja>) that is the <kanji>element</kanji> version of it is an <vocabulary>elementary particle</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I feel like I’ve seen the word "elementary particle" in my physics textbook.
context_sentences.ja: 「素粒子」って言葉は物理の教科書で見た事がある気がするよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>握り</ja> is a "grip." When you add <ja>お</ja> it's elevated a bit. For some reason it becomes a <vocabulary>rice ball</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>onigiri</vocabulary>). To make a rice ball, you use your grip to make them into a ball shape, which is probably where it comes from.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading comes from <ja>握り</ja>.

Note that this is usually written in hiragana as <ja>おにぎり</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I forbade my son from eating convenience store rice balls.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>揚げる</ja> can mean "to deep fry?" Something that was deep fried and then put in front of you is <vocabulary>deep fried</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is <ja>揚げる</ja> and <ja>出す</ja>'s reading.

context_sentences.en: Here is a plate of delicious deep fried tofu I just made.
context_sentences.ja: これは出来たてホカホカの美味しい揚げ出し豆腐ですよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>叫ぶ</ja> is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>叫ぶ</ja>.

context_sentences.en: If you put triple A batteries in this toy and turn on the power, he will scream.
context_sentences.ja: この人形に単四電池を入れて電源を入れると、叫び出すんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>shout</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>yell</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>叫ぶ</ja> and <ja>声</ja>, put together. Careful of the rendaku.

context_sentences.en: Mami lifted the bacon up and down while she screamed.
context_sentences.ja: マミは叫び声を上げながら、ベーコンを上下に動かしました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>sprout</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sprout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bud</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoot</vocabulary>. All sprouts are new, after all.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>manipulate</kanji> something, imagine you're doing it with your <vocabulary>palm</vocabulary>. You use your palm to manipulate the movement, and then you fine tune it further, all with your palm!

Something to note here is that you'll typically see palm in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Where is the <vocabulary>palm of one's hand</vocabulary>? It's on your <reading><ja>手の</ja>here</reading> (<ja>てのひら</ja>). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was."

Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>naked</kanji> <kanji>foot</kanji>, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words <ja>裸</ja> (<ja>はだか</ja>) and <ja>足</ja> (<ja>あし</ja>) were smushed together into one word. The <ja>裸</ja> becomes <ja>はだ</ja> and the <ja>足</ja> becomes <ja>し</ja>. You can think of it this way: You were <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary> too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you <reading>had ashi</reading> (<ja>はだし</ja>) at one point in the past.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>紛らわしい</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<ja>澄む</ja> is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you <reading>mus</reading>t (<ja>ます</ja>) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or <vocabulary>to make something clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to clear something</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to strain</vocabulary> when used together with <ja>耳</ja>, as in <ja>耳を澄ます</ja>, "to strain one's ears".
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<ja>陰</ja> is a shadow, and adding <ja>お</ja> to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary>, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out!

If that's hard to remember, think about shade helping you out. Perhaps <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary> the <kanji>shade</kanji> you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <ja>陰</ja>. <vocabulary>Thanks to</vocabulary> that other vocab word, you can read this one!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>美味しい</ja> by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of <ja>美</ja> you have <ja>不</ja> (not), so something that does <kanji>not</kanji> have <kanji>flavor</kanji> is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary>. This can also refer to someone who's <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary> at something as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's <ja>まずい</ja>. Think about how you're going through this really long <reading>maze</reading> (<ja>まず</ja>) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary> you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly <vocabulary>unappetizing</vocabulary> cheese.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soil</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> on the <kanji>edge</kanji>. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the <vocabulary>edge of a sumo ring</vocabulary>. data.meaning_mnemonic:
When you're <kanji>distract</kanji>ed, everything you do is a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary>. You're not focusing, so it all comes down to <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is mostly written in kana only!
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This uses a different reading than the one you've already learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Somebody was trying to <reading>mug</reading> (<ja>まぐ</ja>) you, but you managed to escape by pure <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary>! Your escape might have just been a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary>, but at least you didn't get mugged!

data.reading_mnemonic: Think about a <vocabulary>threat</vocabulary> being sent to you. It's in the form of bad <reading>odo</reading>r (<ja>おど</ja>). Yuck, what a nasty way to send a threat.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading of <ja>洞</ja> is one you've learned. The reading of <ja>穴</ja> isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary>, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say <ja>ほらあな</ja>, but then you'd never learn that reading for <ja>穴</ja>, and where's the fun in that?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji><ja>歩</ja></kanji> is "walk" and you take <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>walk</kanji>, then really you are just taking <vocabulary>one step</vocabulary>. When there's a number before <ja>歩</ja>, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The <ja>いち</ja> shortens to an <ja>いっ</ja> and the <ja>ほ</ja> rendakus to <ja>ぽ</ja>. One step at a time, right?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji refers to a <kanji>floor</kanji> (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a <ja>〜</ja>. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the <ja>〜</ja> or you'll get it wrong!

context_sentences.en: I live on the thirteenth floor of this apartment.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji <ja>付</ja> means <kanji>attach</kanji> and words like <ja>付く</ja> mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps <vocabulary>included</vocabulary> with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast<ja>付き</ja>, i.e. "<vocabulary>including</vocabulary> breakfast."
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like <ja>付く</ja> and <ja>付ける</ja>.

context_sentences.en: This vacuum cleaner comes with one year warranty.
context_sentences.ja: このそうじきは、一年間のほしょうしょ付きですよ。

context_sentences.en: I'm looking for a Japanese style hotel that includes dinner and breakfast.
context_sentences.ja: 一ぱく二食付きのりょかんをさがしています。

context_sentences.en: This room is furnished with a refrigerator and a washing machine.
context_sentences.ja: この部屋は冷蔵庫、洗濯機付きです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a counter that can be used with various "flat" things, which is why it is referring to a <vocabulary>flat object</vocabulary>. Other things it can refer to include <vocabulary>clothing items</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sheets</vocabulary>, paper, stamps, dishes, and more. Notice how they're all kind of flat shaped?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I have ten tickets for the soccer game on Sunday.
context_sentences.ja: 日曜日のサッカーの試合のチケットを十枚持っています。

context_sentences.en: My breakfast is usually just one slice of toast.
context_sentences.ja: いつもは朝ご飯は食パン一枚だけです。

context_sentences.en: I’d like to buy some Tofugu stickers. How much would one be?
context_sentences.ja: トーフグのステッカーを何枚か買いたいのですが、一枚いくらになりますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: This counter is used with some kind of <kanji>machine</kanji> or device, usually a fairly large one (so nothing itty bitty). Cars are a good example of this. But it can also be used for things like computers, which were once the size of rooms, but are now nice and small. Thanks technology!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the <ja>〜</ja> in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

context_sentences.en: How many buses do we need?
context_sentences.ja: バスはなん台いりますか？

context_sentences.en: I ordered three machines that makes your eyesight better.
context_sentences.ja: し力がよくなるきかいを三台ちゅうもんしました。

context_sentences.en: The rich company president has three luxury cars.
context_sentences.ja: あのかねもちしゃちょうはこうきゅうしゃを三台もっています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s. What does that come out to? <vocabulary>Three hundred</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the <ja>ひゃく</ja> rendakus to <ja>びゃく</ja>. This pattern will repeat itself with <ja>三</ja> + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.

context_sentences.en: I have three hundred manga.
context_sentences.ja: まんがを三百さつもっています。

context_sentences.en: When I was taking a nap, somebody rang the doorbell 300 times.
context_sentences.ja: ひるねをしていた時に、だれかがインターホンを三百回もならした。

context_sentences.en: One year is three hundred and sixty-five days.
context_sentences.ja: 一年は三百六十五日です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>city</kanji> is a <vocabulary>city</vocabulary>. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: This bronze statue of Koichi has become the symbol of this city.

context_sentences.en: I prefer life in the city as opposed to life in the countryside.
context_sentences.ja: いなかよりも、都市での生活の方がいいですね。

context_sentences.en: Do you know any interesting urban legends?
context_sentences.ja: 何かおもしろい都市伝説を知っていますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>say</kanji> words in a <kanji>language</kanji>, you are speaking a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary>. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: What are the popular programming languages right now?

context_sentences.en: I joined an offline gathering where language geeks got together and talk about language all night long.

context_sentences.en: I started to study a new computer language.
context_sentences.ja: 新しいコンピュータ言語の勉強を始めました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>地下</ja>, which is "below ground." Well, this is <kanji>ground</kanji> and <kanji>above</kanji> combined together, so I bet you can guess that this means <vocabulary>above ground</vocabulary>. But usually things above ground don't float (unless you're in space), so it's really <vocabulary>on the ground</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: The leaves fell to the ground.
context_sentences.ja: 木のはが地上におちた。

context_sentences.en: Koichi has a Secret Base 1km above ground.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは地上1kmの所に、ひみつき地をもっている。

context_sentences.en: When you look at Tokyo Tower from the ground it feels tremendously powerful.
context_sentences.ja: 東京タワーは、地上から見上げると物凄い迫力がありますね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s and put them together, you have <vocabulary>all</vocabulary> things. The <vocabulary>entire</vocabulary> collection. It is <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: All of it?
context_sentences.ja: 全部ですか。

context_sentences.en: Who ate the whole box of my bacon cookies?

context_sentences.en: All of these socks have holes.
context_sentences.ja: この靴下、全部穴があいていますよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there's a number before <ja>時</ja>, it means <vocabulary>o'clock</vocabulary>. For example <ja>１時</ja> is 1:00, and <ja>２３時</ja> is 23:00 or 11pm.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: When it’s three o’clock let’s have our afternoon snack break.
context_sentences.ja: 三時になったらおやつ休けいにしましょう。

context_sentences.en: Let's meet up at Koichi's kitchen at 2:30, ok?
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの家の台どころで二時半にまちあわせね。

context_sentences.en: Do you usually do your WaniKani reviews at 3pm?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If we're talking about <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>s, then we might as well be talking about <vocabulary>all people</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>, because that's a lot of people, you know?
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since <ja>万</ja> and <ja>人</ja> both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

<vocabulary>All people</vocabulary> have been <reading>ban</reading>ned from <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (<ja>ばんにん</ja>). Apparently they're working on something super secret, so now <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary> is banned. What could it be?!

context_sentences.en: That actor is popular with everyone.
context_sentences.ja: このアクターは、万人に人気がある。

context_sentences.en: I heard that everybody likes the smell of parakeets.
context_sentences.ja: セキセイインコのにおいって、万人受けするにおいらしい。

context_sentences.en: This seems to be the common impression among everybody.
context_sentences.ja: これは万人に共通の感想だろう。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>flavor</kanji> of this <kanji>direction</kanji> is one I'd like to follow and go in, along with you. You have a good flavor and you're going in a good direction. Will you be my <vocabulary>ally</vocabulary>? I'll be your <vocabulary>supporter</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <ja>味</ja> and the kun'yomi reading for <ja>方</ja>. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to read this word!

context_sentences.en: I thought that at least Tofugu would support me.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグだけは、味方してくれると思ってたんだけどな。

context_sentences.en: Actually, Koichi was an enemy disguised as a friend.
context_sentences.ja: 実は、コウイチは味方のふりをしたてきだったんだよ。

context_sentences.en: Who the heck are your allies?
context_sentences.ja: お前は一体どっちの味方なんだ？

data.meaning_mnemonic: One who <kanji>use</kanji>s <kanji>heaven</kanji> to their advantage is someone from heaven, like an <vocabulary>angel</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: I met a girl who was as cute as an angel.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you see this on a number, for example <ja>７人</ja> or <ja>３人</ja>, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both <ja>一人</ja> and <ja>二人</ja> have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus <ja>にん</ja>, like this. <ja>５人</ja> is <ja>ごにん</ja>, <ja>１０人</ja> is <ja>じゅうにん</ja>, etc. This is the <vocabulary>counter for people</vocabulary>, which makes this word the <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a counter, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since <ja>人</ja> has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Just think of the sheer <vocabulary>number of people</vocabulary> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (<ja>にん</ja>). It must be huge. This really is just a <vocabulary>counter for people</vocabulary> that work at Nintendo.

context_sentences.en: There were 10 people, altogether.
context_sentences.ja: ぜんぶで十人いました。

context_sentences.en: How many workers are in Tofugu?

context_sentences.en: I have three children.
context_sentences.ja: わたしは三人子どもがいます。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <ja>発売</ja>, which means "for sale," and then you have <ja>中</ja> which is <kanji>middle</kanji>. An item that is in the middle of being for sale is <vocabulary>now for sale</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>in stores now</vocabulary> or in other words <vocabulary>now available</vocabulary>. You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>発売</ja> and <ja>中</ja> (kanji reading) put together.

context_sentences.en: Is the Year-End Jumbo Draw Lottery still for sale?
context_sentences.ja: 年末ジャンボたからくじはまだ発売中ですか？

context_sentences.en: This is a tenugui towel that's sold on the Tofugu store.
context_sentences.ja: これは、トーフグストアで発売中の手ぬぐいです。

context_sentences.en: The June issue of Shonen Jump is now on sale, to critical acclaim.
context_sentences.ja: 少年ジャンプ６月号、ただ今絶賛発売中。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>手洗い</ja> is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add <ja>お</ja> you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the <vocabulary>toilet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>restroom</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>. Ewww. Poop goes there.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>手洗い</ja>, so if you know that you'll know this too!

context_sentences.en: The restroom is straight and to the left.
context_sentences.ja: お手洗いは、真っすぐ行って左です。

context_sentences.en: James always takes a sip of whiskey before going to the bathroom.
context_sentences.ja: ジェームスはいつも、お手洗いに行く前にウィスキーを一口飲む。

context_sentences.en: I dozed off while sitting in the bathroom doing my business.
context_sentences.ja: お手洗いで用を足しているうちに、座ったまま寝てしまいました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>attack</kanji>! This is a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> on someone or something, though it can also be an <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> on them. Yep, this is the <ja>進撃</ja> from <ja>進撃の巨人</ja>, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!

context_sentences.en: Do something to halt the enemy's advance!
context_sentences.ja: どうにかして敵の進撃をはばんでくれ！

context_sentences.en: Viet advanced on the enemy.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは敵に進撃した。

context_sentences.en: I’m hooked on Attack on Titan.
context_sentences.ja: 進撃の巨人にはまっています。
